qas.question: "Compensation" is the name of the system used for what type of elevators?

answers.text: Elevators with more than 30 m (98 ft) of travel
a separate set of cables or a chain attached to the bottom of the counterweight and the bottom of the elevator cab

qas.question: What exactly does this system compensate for?

answers.text: the differing weight of cable between the hoist and the cab

qas.question: What is the chain guided by in a compensation system that uses chains?

answers.text: a bar mounted between the counterweight railway lines

context: <a0_0>Elevators with more than 30 m (98 ft) of travel<a0_0/> have a system called compensation. This is <a1_0>a separate set of cables or a chain attached to the bottom of the counterweight and the bottom of the elevator cab<a1_0/>. This makes it easier to control the elevator, as it compensates for <a2_0>the differing weight of cable between the hoist and the cab<a2_0/>. If the elevator cab is at the top of the hoist-way, there is a short length of hoist cable above the car and a long length of compensating cable below the car and vice versa for the counterweight. If the compensation system uses cables, there will be an additional sheave in the pit below the elevator, to guide the cables. If the compensation system uses chains, the chain is guided by <a3_0>a bar mounted between the counterweight railway lines<a3_0/>.
